The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

div.p:
8. What are the Å¿igns of election, but the dying unto Å¿in, poverty of Å¿pirit, a hungring after the righteouÅ¿neÅ¿s that there is in ChriÅ¿t, and prizing of it above all earthly things? a reÅ¿ignation of our Å¿elves into Gods hands, with an acknowledgement

Q. What is vocation or effectual calling?

div.head: The Å¿hortneÅ¿s of mans life, and the miÅ¿ery that doth attend every age and condition of all men that live and delight in Å¿in, and lie down in Sorrow.
div.p:
MAns whole life is but a progreÅ¿s of death, all the time we live we die inviÅ¿ibly, and when we die indeed, it is but a compleating of what we have been doing all our life; the beÅ¿t mens lives are as glaÅ¿s, bright and brittle, and evermore in danger of breaking, Jer. 22. 29. Oh earth, earth, earth, hear the voice of the Lord! And why doth he mention earth three times? 1. BecauÅ¿e we came from the earth. 2. BecauÅ¿e at the beÅ¿t we are but earth. 3. BecauÅ¿e we Å¿hall Å¿peedily return to the earth, as appears

Å¿ometimes to a flower that Å¿prings in the morning, and withereth before night, Job 14. 2 Sometimes to a Weavers Å¿huttle, Job 7. 6. What is Å¿wifter then a Å¿huttle? it flies to and again, forward and backward: Å¿o nights and dayes paÅ¿s this Å¿huttle of our life, forward and backward, to and fro; the night doth caÅ¿t this Å¿huttle to the day, and the day caÅ¿ts it to the night, and the night to the day, and Å¿o from one to the other, forward and backward, to and again; So that between theÅ¿e two, time quickly weaves off the thread of our life, the piece comes to be woven, and Å¿o to be cut off; and juÅ¿t Å¿o is our life, IÅ¿aiah 38. 12. I have cut off like a Weaver.

What Å¿hall I Å¿ay more? For what is our life? it is even as a vapour that appeareth for a little time, and then vaniÅ¿heth away: Å¿uch is the Å¿wiftneÅ¿s of mans dayes, and Å¿hortneÅ¿s of his life, and frailty of his nature, that the Å¿wifteÅ¿t, Å¿horteÅ¿t, and fraileÅ¿t things that we read of in Scripture, are not Å¿wift, Å¿hort, and frail enough

Here I cannot but acquaint the Reader with Å¿ome things that the Lord made of great uÅ¿e to me many years Å¿ince in reading Å¿ome part of the practiÅ¿e of Piety, and auother book called Sincere the Convert, and another little book called Good news from heaven, &c. together with what I have learned from the Scriptures and ChriÅ¿tians, &c. and Å¿o I Å¿hall trace man from his birth to his death, and begin, FirÅ¿t with choÅ¿e that live and die in a Å¿tate of nature; Secondly we Å¿hall lay down, and that in few lines, the bleÅ¿Å¿ed Å¿tate of thoÅ¿e that in their life prepare for death, for death hath Å¿omething to Å¿ay to every man, and would fain be heard, but men are not at leiÅ¿ure to hearken to him, till he throws them upon their Å¿ick beds.

div.head: Of the Condition of man in his birth and infancy.
div.p:
By the pangs, groans, and Å¿truglings, and the violent travell of his mother, the child is produced to the light, many miÅ¿carrying at their birth by divers accidents, the mother and the child periÅ¿h together, but Å¿ometimes by Gods providence after the child hath been impriÅ¿oned nine moneths in an obÅ¿cure priÅ¿on, it Å¿prings into the world, and Å¿o as it were caÅ¿t naked upon the earth all embrued into the blood of filthineÅ¿s, Å¿o that the mother is aÅ¿hamed to let the child know the manner thereof. Oh miÅ¿erable man, where Å¿hall I begin to deÅ¿cribe thine endleÅ¿s miÅ¿ery, who art condemned as Å¿oon as conceived,

div.head: Of mankind in the Å¿tate of childhood.
div.p: THE two firÅ¿t years of it is nothing but impotency and weak imbecility to himÅ¿elf, and charge, trouble and vexation to his parents; other creatures by the benefit of nature can Å¿tand upon their Legs, and Å¿eek after their food, but thou muÅ¿t be Å¿wadled in clouts, and not able to help thy Å¿elf; the yound chickens as Å¿oon as they are hatched, can run after their dam, to Å¿eek for food, the lambs, calves, and yound colts, Å¿tand Å¿uddenly upon their legs to Å¿eek their dams teats: but man would periÅ¿h if his mother did not bring the nipple of her breÅ¿t to his mouth, and rock him upon her knees, and for the three or four years of his infancy, he muÅ¿t be carefully tended for fear he Å¿hould take hurt, left horÅ¿es, carts, or coaches run over him, &c.

div.p: THE greateÅ¿t part of this time is Å¿pent under the reÅ¿traint of their tutors or maÅ¿ters, for youth is as an untamed beaÅ¿t, all whoÅ¿e affections are raÅ¿h, and rude, not capable of good counÅ¿el when it is given, delighting in nothing but toyes and babies, and vanity, and therefore muÅ¿t be kept under the rod and fear of parents and maÅ¿ters, as if thou hadÅ¿t been born to live in Å¿lavery, rather then at the diÅ¿poÅ¿ition of thy own will; no tired horÅ¿es were ever more willing to be rid of their burdens, then thou art to get out of this Å¿tate of bondage, &c. never minding thy Creator in the dayes of thy youth, EccleÅ¿. 12. 1. div.p:
THE maturiry of mans age begins at thirty, and continues till forty five; in this Å¿tate the fleÅ¿h provokes thee to luÅ¿t, the world allures thee to pleaÅ¿ure, and the Devil tempts thee to all kind of Å¿ins, fears of enemies affright thee, Å¿uits in Law do vex thee, wrongs of ill neighbours do oppreÅ¿s thee, cares for wife and children do conÅ¿ume thee, Å¿in Å¿tings thee within, Satan layes Å¿nares before thee, Å¿ins paÅ¿t, dogs behind thee; in this miÅ¿erable eÅ¿tate, whither wilt thou go for reÅ¿t and comfort? the houÅ¿e is full of cares, the Field of toyl, the Sea of Pirats, the Land of

div.p: THis age of man is Å¿ubject to envy and covetouÅ¿neÅ¿s, as the former age was to ambition and carking cares, whereby it appears that mens paÅ¿Å¿ions and Å¿ins, do rather change then forÅ¿ake them, for carnal delights to which young men are moÅ¿t addicted, do change in their delcining age, unto envy and covetouÅ¿neÅ¿s, and Å¿ometimes their avarice doth change to ambition; a godly man at this age is fitter for counÅ¿el then for action, becauÅ¿e their paÅ¿Å¿ions are commonly more moderate, their experiences greatter, their Judgement more Å¿olid, and their counÅ¿els Å¿afer, Job 12. 12. div.p: THE decrepit age of man begins a little after Å¿ixty, and ends when death Å¿trikes them with his dart, Rom. 6. 23. the wages of Å¿in is death, the old age of man, except it be endued with free-grace, and Å¿anctified by the Spirit of God, it is the vanity of vanities, and the miÅ¿ery of all miÅ¿eries, for the innumerous infirmities incident to it, viz. bald-headed, Å¿tooping under dotage, wrinkled face, rotten teeth, Å¿tinking breath, teÅ¿ty with choler, withered with drineÅ¿s, dimmed with blindneÅ¿s, filled with diÅ¿eaÅ¿es, overwhelmed with Å¿ickneÅ¿s, and bowed together with weakneÅ¿s, having little uÅ¿e of any Å¿enÅ¿e, but of the Å¿ence of pain: what Å¿hall I Å¿ay more? trace man from his mothers womb to the grave, & you Å¿hall find him nothing but a piece of vanity in his beÅ¿t eÅ¿tate, PÅ¿. 39. 5. FirÅ¿t in his very conception, they may be extinguiÅ¿hed by ill Å¿cents and vapours, bruiÅ¿es or fals; then in their infancy, by the quinÅ¿ie, convulÅ¿ions, meaÅ¿els or the Å¿mall pox; then in their youth by the Å¿word, pluriÅ¿ie, and burning feavers; then in the next age, apoplexies, bloody fluxes and conÅ¿umptions; then in their declining age by the Å¿tone and the gout, dropÅ¿ies, palÅ¿ies, &c. div.head: Of the Pollution and MiÅ¿ery of the Å¿oul in this life.
div.p: THE underÅ¿tanding is full of vanity, PÅ¿al. 94. 11. 2 Cor. 4. 4. div.p:
DEath in the Scripture is called the King of terrors, and the fear of death makes many Å¿ubject to bondage all their life, for death is a meÅ¿Å¿enger that hath Å¿omething to Å¿ay to every man, and he often Å¿peaks to all, that would fain be heard, but moÅ¿t men are not at leiÅ¿ure to hear what he hath to Å¿ay, no, not till old age, nor then neither; well, after all the forementioned troubles, in comes death, and looks the old man grim and black in the face, and neither pittieth his age, nor regardeth his long endured Dolours, but battereth all the principal parts of his body, and arreÅ¿teth him to appear before the great judge of Heaven and Earth, at the bar of his JuÅ¿tice; then the old man fals into a cold Å¿weat over all his body, and a trembling in all his members; the head aketh, the face waxeth pale, the noÅ¿e black, the eye-Å¿trings break, the tongue faltereth, the throat rotleth: whilÅ¿t he is thus Å¿ummoned to appear at the great aÅ¿Å¿ize of Gods court, behold a quarter SeÅ¿Å¿ions, and goal Delivery is held within him; where reaÅ¿on Å¿its as Judge, and his conÅ¿cience being now awakened, puts in a bill of Inditement; wherein is alleadged, all the evil deeds that ever thou haÅ¿t committed, and the good deeds that ever thou haÅ¿t omitted, and all the curÅ¿es, and Judgements that are due to every Å¿in: Never Å¿uch a bill put up againÅ¿t the greateÅ¿t Traitor in any court of men; thou muÅ¿t

1. Thou art accuÅ¿ed for many Å¿ins of omiÅ¿Å¿ion, in leaving undone many good things, that God in his word required of thee.

19. For a multitude of unknown Å¿ins, that thou hadÅ¿t totally forgotten, committed in the child-hood, youth and man-hood; all thy omiÅ¿sions and commiÅ¿sions will then come into thy mind, and if thou wouldeÅ¿t, thou canÅ¿t not put them out; I know of two precious ChriÅ¿tians, being a long time weak, and like to dye, that did witneÅ¿s to this truth; all the Å¿ins of their youth that they had forgotten, came in remembrance as freÅ¿h as if but now committed.

And whilÅ¿t thy Å¿oul is thus within, out of peace and order; thy wife, children and friends trouble thee as faÅ¿t, to have thee put thy goods in order, Å¿ome crying, Å¿ome craving, Å¿ome pittying, Å¿ome chearing well; In this extremity, the Å¿oul looks every way for help, and Å¿he finds her Å¿elf every way helpleÅ¿s: I Å¿hall here acquaint the Reader, of a paÅ¿Å¿age that I read at leaÅ¿t twenty years ago; which God made of great uÅ¿e to me, viz. WhilÅ¿t The poor man lyeth in this miÅ¿ery, in comes all his wealth to give her maÅ¿ter a viÅ¿it; and in effect Å¿aith this to him: Thus far have I gone with thee, but farther I will not, I have nothing to do in another world: Now therefore maÅ¿ter Å¿hift for your Å¿elf; I will go Å¿eek me a new MaÅ¿ter: Nay, Å¿aith his MaÅ¿ter, I hope thou wilt not Å¿erve me Å¿o, now I have moÅ¿t need of thee; many a nights reÅ¿t have I broken for thee.

Wealth. Not I; nay, I am Å¿ure you Å¿hall anÅ¿wer for me and your Å¿elf too; and to tell you the truth, I doubt the place is too hot for me where thou art going; Look, Look, here comes death; quivering in your lips, quaking in your joynts, Å¿taring in your eyes; I cannot endure the Å¿ight of him: oh draw the curtain, Å¿hift fot thy Å¿elf MaÅ¿ter, and I will Å¿hift for one.

MaÅ¿ter. Oh baÅ¿e vagrant, have I thus entertained thee like a Prince for this? Oh all ye people of the world, be warned by me, a dying man: Lay up TreaÅ¿ure in Heaven, improve thy Talent, redeem thy Time, and give Diligence to make thy Calling and Election Å¿ure: Oh how Å¿uddenly hath death Å¿tollen upon me, like the Sun, which the eye perceives not
